title: Nasa reveals whether life could survive on alien planets orbiting black holes
text:
Illustration of a black hole surrounded by an ‘accretion disk’ of gas, dust and material (Image: Nasa)

Plants, humans, animals and most other organisms on Earth depend on the sun

But could life thrive on a planet orbiting a dark, cruel and pitiless black hole?

Nasa researchers have published a new study exploring whether it would be possible for lifeforms to survive on a world orbiting the biggest of these beasts: supermassive black holes.

These behemoths are so big that the largest ever discovered stretches to almost two hundred billion kilometres wide.

The duo were inspired by the film Interstellar, which tells the story of a group of astronauts who travel through a wormhole near Saturn to explore an ocean world orbiting a black hole and find out if it’s suitable for human habitation.

The Nasa experts start by considering what would happen if our own sun turned into a black hole, concluding that it wouldn’t be quite as much of a disaster as you might expect.

Supermassive holes sit at the centre of galaxies. However, not all of them are surrounded by an accretion disc (Image: Nasa)

‘On the upside, we know that the Earth would not get “sucked in”,’ they wrote in a paper published in early form on the website Arxiv.

‘On the downside, the Sun provides almost all the energy necessary for life on Earth to survive.

‘Without its constant heat flux, the oceans would likely freeze over in a matter of days.’

For a planet to be habitable, its temperature is crucial.

If it’s too far from a star – or if it’s orbiting an object which doesn’t produce enough heat – then water will freeze, making it difficult or impossible for life as we know it to survive.

When a planet’s too near a star and therefore is blasted with enough heat to boil water, it will also be inhospitable.

However, black holes are sometimes surrounded by a hot ‘accretion disk’ which produces heat.

The Nasa scientists added: ‘We also know that many astrophysical black holes can provide their own energy source.

‘In fact, for most observable black holes, this… power outweighs anything attainable from nuclear fusion by many orders of magnitude.

‘So one could naturally imagine that replacing the Sun with a… black hole might not be the end of life on earth after all.’

Sadly, the rest of the Nasa study is not good news for anyone who fancies living near a dark sun.

Firstly, it’s likely that a planet would be ‘tidally locked’ – which means it would always be facing the hole rather than spinning like Earth.

Unless there was some mechanism which distributed heat around the planet, its dark side would be frozen.

If an alien world was close to the accretion disc, it would be bombarded with radiation unless its inhabitants were advanced enough to build some sort of gigantic shield.

In order for it to be habitable yet still heated by the monster’s accretion disc, it would have to be ‘extremely far from the black hole’.

Even then, denizens would face ‘nature’s silent killer: neutrinos’, which are tiny subatomic particles.

And as if that all wasn’t bad enough, we know that time dilates near black holes – which means it effectively slows down so that one year to people living near the beast might the equivalent of many, many years to people dwelling elsewhere.

So if you settle near a black hole, you might take a holiday back home and find everyone you ever knew was dead because time had slowed down for you but stayed the same for people on your home world.

All of which means it’s probably not very likely than an alien civilisation is surviving near a supermassive black hole.
description: If you think living on Earth is bad, wait until you hear about the conditions on worlds orbiting 'supermassive' monsters.
